utterances: Mm-hmm.
Allen, thanks very much.
Good luck with your experiences...
Thank you.
...with new technology, as well.
Thank you very much.
We just have a little bit of time left.
Let me turn to you, Walter Hamilton.
How far do you expect this to go?
How, is this going to be omnipresent?
Yes, I believe that we will see biometrics touching the everyday lives of our citizens within the next five years.
I'm looking at the frequent traveler program that's called Registered Traveler, which is a voluntary program to speed people through airports.

I'm looking at the six million users that are already purchasing at the point-of-sale at groceries stores with their fingerprint technology, the many laptop computers that are being sold today by such companies as Hewlett-Packard, Gateway, Lenovo, are all using biometrics to secure those laptops, cell phones are in, particularly in Asia, almost, a significant percentage of the cell phones being sold in Japan now have fingerprint sensors to protect the information in the cell phone memory, such as monetary value, or photographs, or other personal information.
So I think it's going to happen and we'll see it soon.
Well, thank you both very much for being with us today.
You just heard from Walter Hamilton, chairman of the International Biometric Industry Association, with us from the studios of WUSF, our member station there.
Thanks very much, Mr. Hamilton.
You're welcome.
Glad to be here.
And Maxine Most of Acuity Market Intelligence, with us by phone from San Francisco, nice to hear from you, as well.
My pleasure.
When we come back from a break, Britain's new anti-terrorism law.
We'll find out what they mean by glorification and what they mean by terrorism.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
In India, only one city outside of New Delhi has been visited by two American presidents.
Bill Clinton and George W.
Bush have both singled out the City of Hyderabad as a showpiece of India's economic boom and of U.S./India cooperation.
Hyderabad has become a hub for the multi-national, high-tech and pharmaceutical industries.
It's planning enormous growth, a new international airport, a ring road and a much-enlarged high-tech sector.
Yet progress rarely comes without a price tag and Hyderabad is no exception.
NPR's Philip Reeves filed this reporter's notebook on what might be called the battle of the monolith.
PHILIP REEVES reporting:
Frauke Quader said it's worse in the mornings.
That's when you most often hear the explosions.
Heavy thuds roll across the landscape, each one announcing a new act of destruction.
A battle is being fought in this part of South India, though not with guns or armies.
Quader is from Germany, though she's lived herein Hyderabad for 35 years.
Today she's inspecting the frontline, and she's not happy with what she sees.
See, they are taking down that whole, over there, that whole mountain.
So they're really at it.
We're beside a lake.
The shore opposite looks as if something's taken a gigantic bite out of it.
On a ridge above stands a group of spectacular new buildings.
This is the vanguard of what's known here in Hyderabad as Cyberbad, a rapidly growing high-tech city, home to giants like Microsoft and Dell.
Quader says to make way for Cyberbad's monolithic glass and concreted structures, other monoliths are being removed with dynamite.
Once you cut them down, they're gone.
This whole marvel of nature is gone.
See those high (unintelligible) those white ones?
That is the Sport Village.
And this whole area will be all be Cyberbad.
It's masses of square kilometers.
Hyderabad stands amid one of the oldest rock systems in the world.
Clusters of enormous granite boulders rare up on the skyline.
Geologists say these have been here since they were thrust out of the earth's crust some two and a half billion years ago.
Natural sculptures crafted by wind and rain into exotic shapes.
Everybody sees the beauty of the rock.
First of all, they have these bizarre forms there.
They are balanced on top of each other in such a way that sometimes it's really unbelievable.
It just, you know, it just strikes you that these formations are so beautiful and so unusual.
And it is something you don't see anywhere else.
Quader says some of the more extraordinary granite clusters have been given names.
We have one rock called Bear's Nose.
And then there's Skull Rock over there.
And then we have seen the Cliff Rock.
And we have a Monster Rock, also here in Jubilee Hills, and an obelisk, and a tortoise.
Quader is one of several hundred members of a conservation society, trying to prevent the indiscriminate destruction of Hyderabad's rocks, or as they put it, its rockitecture.
We are standing today on Mahindra Hill.
Anurahda Reddy is another.
We see only two or three large rocky areas left.
Two or three large magnificent rocky outcrops left.
The rest of it has been blasted into oblivion to make houses that we see around us.
Your piece in Slate yesterday, pointed to, not history, but actually the present and the future in terms of media campaigning as a big factor in Ned Lamont's success.
And that is new media, with especially YouTube, the online video site.
What do you mean by that?

Well, we've heard a lot in this race about the bloggers, and one of the things that the bloggers and the online activists that support Lamont have done, and did in this race rather affectively, is they used video on YouTube, and also on Web sites.
And they did a number of things.
They followed Lieberman around and got video of him doing things that would gin up the Lamont supporters.
They also passed around videos from shows like The Colbert Report.
Colbert ran several commentaries in which he essentially lampooned Lieberman.
They were entertaining, witty, and every time one was produced it would circulate among the Lamont supporters, make them laugh, and also keep them engaged in the campaign.
And we have a clip of that tape: Stephen Colbert repeatedly asking Senator Joe Lieberman to appear on his show.
(Soundbite of TV show, The Colbert Report)
Senator the offer still stands.
In fact, I've placed an empty seat here for you.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Much like Jewish families set a place for Elijah at the Passover table, should he care to stop by.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Soundbite of applause)
The Colbert Report making fun of Joe Lieberman.
You think this is an effective campaign tool, a very effective one.
I'll just note your colleague at Slate, Mickey Kaus says YouTube is too small scale to matter, which seems like an odd criticism from a blogger.
But still this is something that's going to matter in campaigning you think?
I do.
Well, as a successful self-promoter of his own video blogging, Mickey Kaus knows that there is a power to video that regular blogging - text doesn't have.
And I think what the Lamont people did is they figured out how to use this new medium to keep their supporters regularly, sort of ginned up, also to kind of catch Lieberman off balance.

And since the Internet and the Web will only become more prevalent in human affairs and not less, we're likely to see that videos of this kind created and circulated by the Lamont campaign will start being used in other campaigns.
And finally John, everyone is saying that this was a referendum on the Iraq war.
Was it?
In part it was, but it was also a referendum on the way that Lieberman treated members of his own party.
And the big debate now is whether you can be a Democrat and speak out against others in your party, and whether you'll be turned out for it.
Whether Lieberman did something that was kind of bucking his party too much and whether that's allowed in the new Democratic Party.
John Dickerson, chief political writer for the online magazine Slate.
John, thank you.
Thank you.
(Soundbite of music)
And there's more coming up on DAY TO DAY.
Just when you think you've heard about as much as you could possibly want to about the royal wedding, our friend A.J.
Jacobs comes along.
A.J.
is Esquire magazine's editor-at-large, famous know-it-all journalist.
He's with us to share some little known doubt aspects of Royal wedding history.
A.J., thanks for coming back.
Mr.
A.J.
JACOBS (Editor-At-Large, Esquire Magazine): Thank you for having me.
This wedding has been described as modest for royal standards, just about $18 million.
Yeah.
So what's a real blowout of a royal wedding?
